Yes, coaches may sometimes make a change in their plan just to surprise their opponents, even if it goes against their team's strength or game plan. This tactic is commonly referred to as a "curveball" or a "surprise move."

A coach may choose to make a surprise move if they feel that their opponent has figured out their typical game plan or if they want to exploit a weakness in their opponent's game. For example, a team known for playing a slow, deliberate offensive style may suddenly switch to a fast-paced style to catch their opponents off guard. Or a coach may decide to use a player who doesn't typically play much, but has a skill that their opponents may not be prepared for.

However, making a surprise move comes with a risk. Coaches must balance the element of surprise with their team's ability to execute the new strategy effectively. If the change in strategy confuses their own team, it may end up backfiring instead of providing an advantage.
